turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Machir (biblical region).
turn.1: What was the biblical region of Machir?
turn.2: Machir (biblical region) Machir was the name of a tribal group mentioned in the Song of Deborah in , where it is praised for fighting alongside five other Israelite tribes: Ephraim, Benjamin, Zebulun, Issachar, and Naphtali.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: The Song of Deborah speaks of officers ("mechokekim") coming from Machir to join the battle against Sisera.
turn.6: The passage appears to reflect an early time in the history of Israel, before Israel was organized as a nation, when it was instead a group of loosely associated tribes.
turn.7: Was there any other tribes mentioned?
turn.8: In the later standardized lists of the Twelve Tribes of Israel, Machir does not appear, but rather the Tribe of Manasseh appears in its place.
turn.10: Machir "may have been an independent clan that was eventually absorbed within Manasseh." Other hypotheses include the idea that Manasseh was originally a clan within Machir which became more prominent than the rest of the tribe, or that Manasseh may have been another group who displaced the Machirites.
turn.11: Did any other groups displace them?
turn.12: According to traditions in the Pentateuch, which view the tribes as descending from the sons of Jacob, Machir was the son of Manasseh, but was legally adopted by Jacob.
